While any causal relationship between climate and HFMD is unknown, speculations include a lower HFMD incidence because of decreased social contact during temperate zonesâ€™ winter.
118, 131 In contrast, increased social contacts during winter have been speculated to facilitate spread of other droplet-borne diseases, such as influenza,
132 which are epidemic in winter. Given the unknowns surrounding this issue, further research is clearly required to ascertain whether meteorologic factors or seasonal social contact patterns is an adequate explanation for the seasonality of HFMD.
